intro.p: The function y = f(x) shown below relates x, {{ivd}}, measured in {{ivu}}, and y, {{dvd}}, measured in {{dvu}}.

content.p: Calculate the average rate of change of f(x) on the interval from x={{Px}} to x={{Qx}}.

outtro.p: The average rate of change is \frac{ f({{Px}}) - f({{Qx}}) }{ {{Px}} - {{Qx}} } = \frac{ {{Py}} - {{Qy}} }{ {{Px}} - {{Qx}} } = {{aroc}}.

content.p: On a copy of the graph below, sketch an additional line that can help the reader understand what your answer to the previous question is saying about f. Explain how your line was chosen, and how it accurately reflects your previous answer.

outtro.p: This is the slope of a secant line drawn on the graph through the points ({{Px}},{{Py}}) and ({{Qx}}, {{Qy}}).
This picture makes sense because the average rate of change we computed was {{sign}} and this secant line is {{direction}}.

content.p: Finally, write a "when...then" sentence that explains the practical interpretation of your numerical answer to part (a). Be sure to include both the number and its units in your explanation.
For example: "When the population of Boston increases from 2 million residents to 3 million residents, then the level of the water table decreases at a rate of 1.6 feet per million people."

outtro.p: When {{ivd}} increases from {{Px}} {{ivu}} to {{Qx}} {{ivu}}, then {{dvd}} {{dvdelta}} at a rate of {{aaroc}} {{dvu}} per {{ivu}}.
